definition: priority/whether sth is urgent
slow/unhurried/sluggish/gradual/not tense/relaxed/to postpone/to defer/to stall/to stave off/to revive/to recuperate
urgent/pressing/rapid/hurried/worried/to make (sb) anxious
slight or important, urgent or non-urgent (idiom); to deal with important matters first/sense of priority
slight or important, urgent or non-urgent (idiom); to deal with important matters first/sense of priority/also written 輕重緩急|轻重缓急
to help one another in difficulty/mutual assistance in extremity

sentences.english: Serve the citizens in order of priority and urgency on practical affair, take the easiest the first .
sentences.chinese: 我们为市民办实事要分轻重缓急，先易后难。

sentences.english: Tan pointed out that the government had established priorities.
sentences.chinese: 谭富卞指出政府已定下了轻重缓急。

sentences.english: Understand the urgency of the situation.
The Froude number of flow is the factor of flow status: supercritical flow or subcritical flow.
sentences.chinese: 由流体流动的福劳德数可以确定流动的缓急程度。

sentences.english: This person should be able to easily answer the questions on setting priorities.
sentences.chinese: 应聘人应该能轻松的回答有关决定轻重缓急的问题。

sentences.english: It was a matter of balancing priorities.
sentences.chinese: 这是一个权衡轻重缓急的问题。

sentences.english: Learnd to set priorities and make decisions.
sentences.chinese: 学会分清轻重缓急和做决定。

definition: slight or important, urgent or non-urgent (idiom); to deal with important matters first/sense of priority/also written 輕重緩急|轻重缓急
severity (of the case)/degree of seriousness/whether sth is slight or serious
lit. crooked and straight/fig. right and wrong, good and evil
reinforcing and reducing methods (in acupuncture)
orderly and logical (of writing)/luxuriant/flourishing/prosperous
to urge/urgent/pressing
modulation (rising and falling pitch)/intonation/a cadence/to rise and fall (of a body floating in water)
complicated and simple/traditional and simplified form of Chinese characters
to feel (take) the pulse
to advance or retreat/knowing when to come and when to leave/a sense of propriety
the whole course of an event from beginning to end/ins and outs/the fundamental and the incidental
depth (archaic)
stubborn/contrary/disobedient
close and distant (relatives)
the many or the few
